header.overview: The header defines a macro used to simplify the invocations of .

macro.abstract: The macro is used to simplify the invocations of .

usage.param: This argument must be empty (i.e. a placemarker).
The expression to be evaluated in the context of e.

macro.para: This macro is overloaded. The first form of this macro, (), expands to the current . The second form expands to __VA_ARGS__.

Neither e or __VA_ARGS__ is allowed to expand on input. In the case of __VA_ARGS__, this pulls the expansion into the context of the macro name resulting from (e). Each e, which are integers ranging from 1 to , yields a unique macro name and, therefore, a unique context.

The purpose of this macro is define a small set of entry points that clean up the invocation syntax of . These invocations usually follow one of the following patterns:
(MACRO(...))
(s)(MACRO_S(s, ...))
Given a theoretical MACRO, the macro can be used to easily map the complex (and more open-ended) invocation syntax to a much simpler one. For example,
#define AUTO_MACRO (AUTO_MACRO_, ())
#define AUTO_MACRO_1(...) \ (1)(, (MACRO(__VA_ARGS__))) \ /**/ #define AUTO_MACRO_2(...) \ (2)(, (MACRO(__VA_ARGS__))) \ /**/
/* ... */
#define AUTO_MACRO_8(...) \ (8)(, (MACRO(__VA_ARGS__))) \ /**/
This code maps the invocation syntax from (MACRO(...)) to AUTO_MACRO(...).
The library defines only --currently 8. The theoretically allows entry points. However, while many may be used, it is unusual to use more the a very small number of entry points.

In order to make a standalone expression such as MACRO(...) operate recursively, MACRO must be an object-like macro that expands to some other macro name that is not currently disabled. That implies, that for eight entry points, eight unique macros are required (such as the AUTO_MACRO_1 through AUTO_MACRO_8 macros above). This is why the library only supports --more are rarely needed and increasing their number increases macro replication across all constructs that use it.

If such a mapping is used, a should provide because the entry points may be shared across many constructs. Thus, for example, AUTO_MACRO may be invoked only for the first time and still expand to something other than AUTO_MACRO_1 because an invoking macro may have already used the first . Because of this, a mapping implementation might want to trigger a compile-time assertion if happens to increase to a number greater than the number of entry-point macros. For example,
#if > 8 #error The AUTO_MACRO implementation needs to be extended. #endif
